3.54.text:
Ian Dejardin:– Any questions? Oh go on.
Okay, I’ll fire one off. I was just rather

18.06.text:
intrigued, but just that last point I was
making about the difficulty of reading a face

24.73.text:
in a portrait of two hundred years ago. But
of course, this is true of almost any face

29.97.text:
and we’ve noticed several examples in this
afternoon’s presentations. The way in which

37.73.text:
Kathleen Scott, for instance, chose to be
photographed dressed to the nines never actually

44.00.text:
up to her elbows in clay, which must have
been her real life. And the one that I just

49.03.text:
wanted to ask about was the photograph of
Vanessa Bell with, I think it was Julian or

57.22.text:
Quentin, one of the two, possibly both, on
her lap. And I've rarely seen anyone look

63.88.text:
so oppressed in all my life and do we think
in the case of Vanessa Bell, is there a reaction

73.40.text:
to the process of being photographed or is
that because she hates being photographed

79.07.text:
or do you think there’s something going
on there about hating being photographed with

84.26.text:
Ian Dejardin:– That’s one for Samantha,
sorry.

85.98.text:
Samantha Wilson:– I speak as someone who
hates being photographed myself so I can,

90.68.text:
kind of, sympathise with it. I think there
was a division in Bell’s life between her

98.75.text:
role and her family and I think the way we
look at it now is that it was purely her family

103.16.text:
that she responded to. Like I said in my first
quote, she wasn’t sure how she’d be practically

110.37.text:
as a parent so I think she did come from a
strict Victorian upbringing, her father and

115.92.text:
her mother, as you said, was a renowned beauty
so I think there was some kind of conflict

123.09.text:
between the way she was brought up and the
way she tried to live her adult life as free

127.89.text:
spirited. And I don’t think necessarily
posing as ‘mommy dearest’ came as naturally

136.14.text:
to her as maybe it might of done, or that
might be just the way we look at it now with

141.24.text:
the hindsight of knowing what she, you know,
how she ended up living her life.

145.73.text:
Ian Dejardin:– I know I’d love to see
a neuro-portrait of that particular photograph.

151.01.text:
I think it would be extremely interesting.
And if I can carry on, unless someone is willing

158.06.text:
to dive in? Oh go on, please Wendy.
Delegate:– I think one of the interesting

169.88.text:
questions around that photograph is: who took
the photograph? Because quite a lot of those

174.48.text:
defining early photographs of Vanessa Bell
were photographs that she took of herself

179.50.text:
using a timer. So may have been.... because
I looked at that photograph and thought, gosh

185.15.text:
that looks like a depressed woman. But she
may have been leaning down to attend to the

191.27.text:
timer that took the image, I don’t know.
Ian Dejardin:– And of course, we never know.

194.74.text:
That’s exactly the point, isn't it? It's
so hard to know, you.... There’s a great

198.37.text:
danger there in projecting onto photographs
and works of art, I suppose you may be interpreting,

205.24.text:
but on the other hand in terms of engagement,
you would argue differently Louise, wouldn’t

211.35.text:
you?
Louise Campion:– Yes, in terms of creating

219.62.text:
a neuro-portrait based on that. I mean, I
think it's really interesting. I've thought

223.49.text:
a lot about the project I've just talked about
and maybe, you know, projecting things that

232.79.text:
you're feeling onto portraits and is that
really what was happening? We’re projecting

239.18.text:
our own feelings or people’s feelings onto
those portraits or were they responding to

245.86.text:
what was there? And I think there's always
a two-way interaction so what any image you

254.21.text:
look at you project onto it things that you
feel and you know about but at the same time

260.51.text:
you respond to what you see so it's a two-way.
So, your question about her looking depressed

269.12.text:
and what was going on, that may also tell
us something about you.

275.54.text:
Ian Dejardin:– Let’s not talk about me.
Do we think that oral histories play their

284.38.text:
role in actually elucidating this issue? I
mean, the whole idea of.... I loved that aspect

290.93.text:
of your project, the ‘Staying Power’ project,
of getting people to talk and using that alongside

299.90.text:
the imagery and the build-up of the collection
at the same time. Is that the really valuable

305.10.text:
thing that helps us to interpret and engage
with objects and visual images?

310.77.text:
Janet Browne:– Yes I think so, but then
I suppose I’ve got my learning and my, sort

314.38.text:
of, teacher educator hat on. You know, because
people, we all kind of come to things from

319.48.text:
different stand points and I think what I
found was when the exhibition, particularly

324.70.text:
at the exhibition of the Black Cultural Archives
when I was working there at the time, we would

330.30.text:
ask people if they wanted an audio guide to
listen to some of the oral histories. A lot

333.59.text:
of people said: no, I just want to go around
and have a look at the photographs first and

339.27.text:
then come back and maybe pick up an audio
guide, because.... And it's, a lot of people

345.30.text:
who could resonate, they sort of knew the
story, a little bit. They had a lived experience

352.99.text:
so they sort of, they didn’t want to listen
to the photographers, necessarily, or the

361.48.text:
subjects. They wanted to, kind of, have their
own thinking and they didn’t want that thinking

366.01.text:
marred and then they would come back and because,
you know, they could pick up an audio guide

370.22.text:
and then go back in and then listen to the
stories. And then there are other people who,

377.53.text:
maybe younger people or people who would be
researching, who would pick up an audio guide

382.80.text:
and go in, because they might not be so familiar.
Well, I'm not saying that’s everybody, but

387.23.text:
what we found was a lot of people who were
familiar with the story, kind of, wanted to

392.32.text:
see it from their point of view first of all
and a lot of the events that we ran around

396.64.text:
particularly the Black Cultural Archives was
very much around people telling their story

403.58.text:
through the photographs because you are engaging
with an audience who were discerning.

410.91.text:
So either because it was intergenerational
and a father talking to their son about what

416.98.text:
was going on there at the time, or somebody
who could actually talk about their own experience…

423.17.text:
Or they were there, lots of people talking
about, well I was there and I know that person

426.87.text:
and people talking about people that they
knew in those photographs because they were

431.51.text:
local so it was local to them. And even people
who came down from Birmingham and saw, you

437.33.text:
know, Pogus Caesar’s bath after the uprisings
in Birmingham and saw the flying bath landing

444.25.text:
on the floor, on the ground in the street.
They were there and will tell you those stories

449.44.text:
about, oh it wasn’t a race riot. Don’t
believe them, it wasn’t a race riot, it

453.75.text:
had to do with all working class people coming
together and saying to the authorities, we’re

461.62.text:
not happy. And so it was different people
had their own stories that brought their own

466.46.text:
narratives to those images.
Ian Dejardin:– The value of a counterpoint.

471.77.text:
Question over here?
Delegate:– Hello, hi, I'm speaking from

475.11.text:
a.... I'm a mental health support worker and
I take people around galleries and I think

479.74.text:
both the oral histories and the neuro-portraits
are fantastic ways of engaging people with

487.49.text:
the idea about identity but also about imagery.
Because the problem with some of the imaging

495.94.text:
we get is that there is a lot of belief that
that imagery is meaningful but I think it

504.84.text:
is about the experience and the discussion
that happens afterwards as well as being able

510.78.text:
to relate to that.
I noticed in the neuro images that there was

516.43.text:
a lot of reference to the images that were
shown to them in terms of the blue and yellow

521.98.text:
and I think that’s a wonderful way of projecting
our understanding of mental health now back

528.62.text:
into those days. And so I’m just wondering
about how much conversation those images and

537.31.text:
those exhibitions have brought in the community
in terms of understanding the social aspects?

543.06.text:
Because that’s what I heard most from looking
back at the stories is seeing that it's not

550.05.text:
an illness identity that sometimes the neuro
imaging pictures would stigmatise people into....

556.51.text:
A lot of people reject, ‘that’s a depressed
brain’ or ‘that’s a normal brain’

560.90.text:
and so it becomes stigmatising as well. But
the stories about people’s experiences and

565.93.text:
lives and being able to relate them back to
current social situations as well, how much

573.19.text:
those exhibitions have brought that forward
to the communities.

580.28.text:
Louise Campion:– Yes, I know that we did
have quite a few conversations about that

587.64.text:
kind of scientific way of talking and some
people were very uncomfortable with it and

597.90.text:
didn’t recognise their own experience, maybe
of their own mental health they didn’t recognise

607.50.text:
that description of it. Certainly somebody
with Asperger’s was, you know, quite angry

619.35.text:
about the way that condition was described,
the neurological way that was described to

624.91.text:
him and actually produced a piece which we
didn’t show, which kind of, was an answer

632.34.text:
to that and said something very different.
But he felt that by creating that piece of

640.83.text:
art he had a voice to say something, yeah,
about the condition that maybe people didn’t

650.34.text:
know. I mean, we didn’t collect evaluation.
We didn’t have, you know, from the general

660.91.text:
public, we had a book which people wrote in.
But we didn’t formally evaluate or you know.

667.68.text:
So it's hard to say but I know anecdotally
a lot of people that saw the exhibition, and

674.97.text:
certainly people from Mind came and talked
to me about that exhibition and the work.

685.65.text:
Ian Dejardin:– We might have time for one
more question but I know people want to get

690.33.text:
home probably. If there is anyone else? Okay,
oh there's one. I saw a twitch. It's too late

701.60.text:
now.
Delegate:– It's just a really quick question,

703.23.text:
it's to throw back to the.... Sorry, to Alice,
I thank you so much for your paper and everybody

710.05.text:
else, it was all fab, but what kind of Black
portraits and pictures of Black people would

717.75.text:
you like to see? You throw it out to us and
I’d just love really quickly to hear what

722.72.text:
you would like to see or kind of, top tips
for us?

725.41.text:
Dr Alice Correia:– Well I think that some
of those last images that I showed are really

735.19.text:
good counterpoints. And some of the images
that are in ‘Staying Power’, I think the

741.47.text:
whole point as I can understand your session,
the whole point for that project was to challenge

751.83.text:
some of the negative stereotypes that circulate
around representations of Blackness. So certainly,

758.84.text:
some of the images that we saw today were
fantastic antidotes. I guess my question is,

769.75.text:
in that exhibition ‘Let The Canvas Come
to Life with Dark Faces’, it had a whole

775.39.text:
range of artists working in paint, in print,
in graphic photographic media and they simply

785.70.text:
weren't collected and so I don’t know where
some of those images are that I showed. I

792.25.text:
just found them in the catalogue and I thought,
‘oh that’s amazing, that’s an amazing

797.16.text:
looking painting as far as I can tell’.
But I have no idea where it is or how to get

802.07.text:
in touch with the artist so there is still
lots of work to be done in investigating and

807.31.text:
digging and I think that’s all of our jobs
really, so yes.

812.41.text:
Ian Dejardin:– Okay, I think I will wind
proceedings up. Now, I’d just like to thank

821.10.text:
all of our speakers, not just this afternoon
but this morning as well. I've had a wonderful

826.37.text:
day. It's been fascinating throughout and
so my thanks to Caroline whose just sneaking

831.39.text:
away at the back there for a wonderful job
she’s done organising. My thanks also to

836.81.text:
Nick Cullinan for letting us have this day
here and for welcoming us this morning. Thank

843.06.text: you all and safe journey home. Thank you.
